awd_titl_txt: Developing a Generalized Storyline that Organizes the Supports for Evidence-based Modeling of Long-Term Impacts of Disturbances in Complex Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

This project will support students to develop evidence-based explanations for the impact of disturbances on complex systems. The project will focus on middle school environmental science disciplinary core ideas in life, Earth, and physical sciences.  There are a wide variety of complex systems principles at work in disturbance ecology. This project serves as a starting point on supporting students to coordinate different sources of information to parse out the direct and indirect effects of disturbances on components of a system and to examine the interconnections between components to predict whether a system will return to equilibrium (resilience) or the system will change into a new state (hysteresis). These same complex systems principles can be applied to other scientific phenomena, such as homeostasis and the spread of infectious disease.  This project will bring the excitement of Luquillo Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) to classrooms outside of Puerto Rico, and has a special emphasis on low performing, low income, high minority schools in Chicago. Over 6000 students will directly benefit from participation in the research program. The units will be incorporated into the Journey to El Yunque web site for dissemination throughout Chicago Public Schools (CPS) and the LTER network. The units will be submitted for review at the Achieve network, thus extending the reach to teachers around the country. The project will impact science teachers and curriculum designers through an online course on storyline development. This project aims to improve students' ability to engage in argument from evidence and address what the literature has identified as a significant challenge, namely the ability to evaluate evidence. Researchers will also demonstrate how it is possible to make progress on implementing Next Generation Science Standards in low performing schools. Through the web-based platform, these results can be replicated across many other school districts.

Researchers will to use the scientific context of the LTER program to develop a generalized storyline template for using evidence-based modeling to teach basic principles of disturbance ecology. Though a co-design process with middle school teachers in CPS, researchers will test the application of learning principles to a generalized storyline template by developing and evaluating three units on disturbance ecology - one life science, one Earth system science, and one physical science. Through a task analysis, researchers have identified three key areas of support for students to be successful at explaining how a system will respond to a disturbance. First, students need to be able to record evidence in a manner that will guide them to developing their explanation. Causal model diagrams have been used successfully in the past to organize evidence, but little is known about how students can use their causal diagrams for developing explanations. Second, there have been a wide variety of scaffolds developed to support the evaluation of scientific arguments, but less is known about how to support students in organizing their evidence to produce scientific arguments. Third, evidence-based modeling and scientific argumentation are not tasks that can be successfully accomplished by following a recipe. Students need to develop a task model to understand the reason why they are engaged in a particular task and how that task will contribute to the primary goal of explanation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on supporting students to develop evidence-based explanations for the impact of disturbances on complex systems. We focused on supporting students to coordinate different sources of information to parse out the direct and indirect effects of disturbances on components of a system and to examine the interconnections between components to predict whether a system will return to equilibrium (resilience) or the system will change into a new state (hysteresis). 

Intellectual Merit

We used the scientific context of the Luquillo LTER program and the oak restoration efforts at the Morton Arboretum to develop a generalized storyline template for using evidence-based modeling to teach basic principles of disturbance ecology. Through a co-design process with middle school teachers in the Chicago Public Schools (CPS), and expanded to include teachers in Arbor Park, IL and River Grove, IL, we tested the application of learning principles to a generalized disturbance storyline template by expanding the Journey to El Yunque population dynamics unit and developing the Tree Guardians unit based on science at the Morton Arboretum.  

(1) The first disturbance storyline routine is the exploration of an anchoring phenomenon routine in which students are introduced to the phenomenon and make observations and initial explanations. In Journey to El Yunque, students experience the phenomenon of hurricane disturbance through a panel of illustrations of what the rainforest looks like at different stages of recovery. For Tree Guardians, students watch a video of scenes from the Morton and examine interactive graphs related to the decline of oak trees over the last 200 years.

(2) The second routine is the navigation routine in which students are guided to reflect on what has been figured out so far in the investigation and what additional questions would guide the next steps in the investigation. We developed an Investigation Steps chart to support the navigation routine by asking students to reflect on what they have figured out so far and what they still need to figure out. 

(3) The third routine is the investigation routine in which students use scientific practices to make progress on figuring out the phenomenon. For the disturbance storyline template, the students’ investigation routine involves the scientific practices of obtaining information and modeling. This routine involves the scientific practices of obtaining information by critically reading scientific texts for evidence about the natural world and developing models that show the relationships among variables, and how changes to those variables might affect the system. 

(4) The fourth routine is the problematizing routine in which students explore additional data about the phenomenon that is meant to elicit disagreement or competing explanations. In the investigation routine students explored how the system works in general. In the disturbance storyline problematizing routine, students use simulation models to explore how the system responds to disturbances. In this step, students engage in the scientific practices of using a model, revising a model, and analyzing data using graphical displays to identify relationships. 

(5) The fifth routine is the putting the pieces together routine in which students consolidate their ideas and evidence to develop an argument based on applying their understanding to explain the disturbance phenomenon. Students used their evidence from a specific disturbance event such as the impact of Hurricane Hugo on species in the El Yunque rainforest and the restoration of oak trees in Illinois. Students process and sort the evidence they have collected to propose a scientific argument that explains the anchoring phenomenon.

Our research results provide evidence for the validity of the disturbance storyline routine. Having students take on authentic scientific identities predicted increased quality of scientific arguments and increased understanding of population dynamics. Whereas students who see the main point of a unit as learning DCIs are less likely to include evidence in their scientific argument. The Investigation Steps Charts helped students with assessing the relevance of evidence. Students who connected evidence and reasoning in the sorting phase were more likely to make those connections in their final scientific argument.

In our field test of Journey to El Yunque and Tree Guardians, we scored the quality of students’ final arguments and related those scores to the development understanding of population dynamics. The quality of students’ arguments correlated with the posttest of ecology understanding, after controlling for pretest knowledge. These results suggest there is a link between the practice of scientific argumentation and the development of understanding of population dynamics. 

 Broader Impacts

Journey to El Yunque and Tree Guardians bring the excitement of science research to classrooms. These programs support broadening participation as they led to increased attitudes towards science and increased interested in pursuing science regardless of race/ethnicity and gender. In the last year, Journey to El Yunque has averaged over 1200 unique visitors per month. Since its launch in April 2024, Tree Guardians have average over 325 unique visitors per month.
